project.title: AI-Enabled Digital Twin of a Solar Photovoltaic Plant for Enhanced Renewable Integration in Bangladesh
project.tagline: A government-funded digital twin framework for real-time solar forecasting and grid-aware analytics.
highlights: Government-funded project supported by Bangladesh Energy and Power Research Council (BEPRC).
Total grant of BDT 1.63 crore (inclusive of VAT and taxes).
Development of a 100 kWp grid-connected rooftop PV test-bed at MIST.
AI-enabled digital twin for real-time monitoring, forecasting, and advanced analytics.
Validation against a 7.6 MWp utility-scale solar PV plant in Sirajganj, Bangladesh.
Creation of a high-resolution solar PV dataset tailored to Bangladesh.

funding.agency: Bangladesh Energy and Power Research Council (BEPRC)
funding.amountDisplay: BDT 1.63 crore (inclusive of VAT and taxes)
funding.summary: The project is fully funded by the Government of Bangladesh through BEPRC with a total allocation of BDT 1.63 crore. The grant covers the design and implementation of a 100 kWp rooftop PV test-bed, weather and communication infrastructure, AI modelling, validation on large-scale plants, and dissemination activities.
funding.notes: Funding is released over 13 milestone-based disbursements between FY 2025–26 and 2028–29, subject to satisfactory technical and financial progress.

sections.overview: This project develops a national-scale, AI-enabled digital twin (DT) framework for grid-connected solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. Using high-resolution data from a 100 kWp rooftop PV test-bed at MIST and operational measurements from large-scale plants, the digital twin will support real-time monitoring, forecasting, and scenario analysis. The work directly supports Bangladesh's strategy to increase renewable penetration while maintaining grid reliability and operational efficiency.
sections.motivation: The rapid expansion of solar PV in Bangladesh introduces variability and uncertainty into power system operation. Grid operators have limited visibility of real-time PV output, and detailed EMT-based models of large PV portfolios are computationally expensive. There is also a lack of curated, high-quality datasets capturing local climatic and operational conditions. An AI-enabled digital twin offers a scalable solution by combining physical data, advanced learning algorithms, and system-level analytics to provide fast, accurate estimates of PV behaviour at different temporal and spatial scales.
objectives: To develop a scalable digital twin model for a 100 kWp grid-connected rooftop PV system at MIST, designed to emulate the behaviour of utility-scale solar plants.
To integrate machine learning and deep learning algorithms into the digital twin for real-time monitoring and multi-horizon forecasting of PV output.
To evaluate the accuracy of the digital twin by comparing its outputs with high-resolution measurements from the 100 kWp test-bed.
To demonstrate the scalability of the developed architecture on smaller PV systems in the 20–50 kWp range.
To validate the digital twin against operational data from a 7.6 MWp solar power plant in Sirajganj, Bangladesh.
To build and publish a comprehensive, multi-feature solar PV dataset specific to Bangladesh for future research and policy analysis.

methodology.title: Physical Test-Bed Implementation
methodology.description: Design and deploy a 100 kWp grid-connected rooftop PV system on the ECE Faculty Building at MIST, including PV modules, inverters, energy storage, mounting structures, and balance-of-system components.

methodology.title: Data Acquisition and Communication
methodology.description: Install and integrate a weather station, digital instrumentation, PMU and data loggers, along with a secure communication infrastructure to collect time-synchronised environmental and electrical data from the test-bed.

methodology.title: Digital Twin Architecture
methodology.description: Develop a modular digital twin architecture that ingests real-time data, applies signal conditioning and feature extraction, and runs AI models to estimate and forecast PV behaviour across multiple time horizons.

methodology.title: AI Modelling and Advanced Analytics
methodology.description: Apply machine learning and deep learning techniques to build forecasting, anomaly detection, and performance benchmarking models that can support grid-aware operational decisions.

methodology.title: Scaling and Validation on Real-World Plants
methodology.description: Extend and validate the digital twin using data from smaller distributed PV systems and a 7.6 MWp solar PV plant in Sirajganj, assessing scalability, robustness, and potential for integration with utility control centres.

impact: Provision of a real-time, AI-enabled digital twin platform to support monitoring and forecasting of solar PV generation in Bangladesh.
Reduction of computational burden in large-scale PV integration studies by offering a digital twin that approximates plant behaviour without modelling every component in detail.
Improved grid reliability and situational awareness for system operators through predictive and diagnostic analytics.
Establishment of a reusable architecture for deploying digital twins in energy management centres and utility control rooms.
Creation of a high-quality, Bangladesh-specific solar dataset that can be used by researchers, policymakers, and industry partners.
Strengthening of national capacity in AI, smart grids, and renewable energy systems through collaborative work between academia and government.
